biosteam.units.design_tools.compute_vacuum_system_power_and_cost(F_mass, F_vol, P_suction, vessel_volume, vacuum_system_preference=None)[source]Â¶

Return power (kW) and cost (USD) of vacuum system.

Parameters

  • F_mass (float) â Vapor mass flow rate entering vacuum system from vessel in kg/hr (not including inleakage).

  • F_vol (float) â Vapor volumetric flow rate entering vacuum system from vessel in m3/hr (not including inleakage).

  • P_suction (float) â Suction pressure in Pa

  • vessel_volume (float) â Vacuum volume in m3

  • vacuum_system_preference ('Liquid-ring pump', 'Steam-jet ejector', or 'Dry-vacuum pump') â Name(s) of preferred vacuum systems

biosteam.units.design_tools.compute_horizontal_vessel_purchase_cost(W, D, F_M)[source]Â¶

Return the purchase cost [Cp; in USD] of a horizontal vessel, including thes cost of platforms and ladders.

Parameters

  • W (float) â Weight [lb].

  • D (float) â Diameter [ft].

  • F_M (float) â Vessel material factor.

Notes

The purchase cost is given by [1]_. See source code for details. The purchase cost is scaled according to BioSTEAMâs Chemical Plant Cost Index, biosteam.CE.

References

1

Seider, W. D., Lewin, D. R., Seader, J. D., Widagdo, S., Gani, R., & Ng, M. K. (2017). Product and Process Design Principles. Wiley. Cost Accounting and Capital Cost Estimation (Chapter 16)

biosteam.units.design_tools.heuristic_overall_heat_transfer_coefficient(ci, hi, co, ho)[source]Â¶

Return a heuristic estimate of the overall heat transfer coefficient [U; in kW/m^2/K]. Assume U is 0.5 kW/m^2/K if heat exchange is sensible and 1.0 kW/m^2/K otherwise.

Parameters

  • ci (Stream) â Cold inlet stream.

  • hi (Stream) â Hot inlet stream.

  • co (Stream) â Cold outlet stream.

  • ho (Stream) â Hot outlet stream.

Returns

U â overall heat transfer coefficient [kW/m^2/K].

Return type

float

biosteam.units.design_tools.heuristic_pressure_drop(inlet_phase, outlet_phase)[source]Â¶

Return a heuristic estimate of the pressure drop [dP; in psi]. If the fluid changes phase, dP is 1.5 psi. If the fluid remains a liquid, dP is 5 psi. If the fluid remains a gas, dP is 3 psi.

Parameters

  • inlet_phase (str) â

  • outlet_phase (str) â

Returns

dP â Pressure drop [psi].

Return type

float

biosteam.units.design_tools.compute_Fahkeri_LMTD_correction_factor(Tci, Thi, Tco, Tho, N_shells)[source]Â¶

Return the log-mean temperature difference correction factor Ft for a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with one or an even number of tube passes, and a given number of shell passes, with the expression given in [1]_ and also shown in 2.

If R = 1 and logarithms cannot be evaluated:

Parameters

  • Tci (float) â Inlet temperature of cold fluid, [K]

  • Thi (float) â Inlet temperature of hot fluid, [K]

  • Tco (float) â Outlet temperature of cold fluid, [K]

  • Tho (float) â Outlet temperature of hot fluid, [K]

  • shells (int, optional) â Number of shell-side passes, [-]

Returns

Ft â Log-mean temperature difference correction factor, [-]

Return type

float

Notes

This expression is symmetric - the same result is calculated if the cold side values are swapped with the hot side values. It also does not depend on the units of the temperature given.

Examples

compute_Fahkeri_LMTD_correction_factor(Tci=15, Tco=85, Thi=130, Tho=110, N_shells=1) 0.9438358829645933

References

1

Fakheri, Ahmad. âA General Expression for the Determination of the Log Mean Temperature Correction Factor for Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers.â Journal of Heat Transfer 125, no. 3 (May 20, 2003): 527-30. doi:10.1115/1.1571078.

2

Hall, Stephen. Rules of Thumb for Chemical Engineers, Fifth Edition. Oxford; Waltham, MA: Butterworth-Heinemann, 2012.

Return required heat transfer area by LMTD correction factor method.

Parameters

  • LMTD (float) â Log mean temperature difference

  • U (float) â Heat transfer coefficient

  • Q (float) â Duty

biosteam.units.design_tools.compute_LMTD(Thi, Tho, Tci, Tco, counterflow=True)[source]Â¶

Return the log-mean temperature difference of an ideal counterflow or co-current heat exchanger.

Parameters

  • Thi (float) â Inlet temperature of hot fluid [K].

  • Tho (float) â Outlet temperature of hot fluid [K].

  • Tci (float) â Inlet temperature of cold fluid [K].

  • Tco (float) â Outlet temperature of cold fluid [K].

  • counterflow (bool, optional) â Whether the exchanger is counterflow or co-current.

Returns

LMTD â Log-mean temperature difference [K]

Return type

float

Notes

Any consistent set of units produces a consistent output.

Examples

>>> LMTD(100., 60., 30., 40.2)
43.200409294131525
>>> LMTD(100., 60., 30., 40.2, counterflow=False)
39.75251118049003
